subject: Gardening
title: Nitrogen Fixers as Companions
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Nitrogen Fixers as Companions.

hook.text: Clover doesn't just sit in your lawn looking pretty. It's manufacturing fertilizer underground, for free.

buildup.text: Legumesâ€”clover, beans, peas, vetchâ€”host Rhizobium bacteria in root nodules that convert nitrogen gas into plant food.

discovery.text: When legume roots die or are cut, that fixed nitrogen releases into the soil for neighboring plants to absorb.

twist.text: Living legumes don't share much nitrogen. The real benefit comes when they're cut downâ€”used as 'chop and drop' mulch.

climax.text: Nitrogen-fixing companions are garden investments: grow them, cut them, and let them feed the next round of crops.

punchline.text: Clover is a free fertilizer factory in your soil.

quiz.question: When do nitrogen-fixing companion plants release the most nitrogen to neighbors?
options: Continuously while they are alive and growing
When their roots die or plants are cut down and decompose
Only during flowering when bacterial activity peaks
